content.description:
Start up the first 2 bolts of the Wasp, then move left through a powerful transition (crux) to better holds. Catch the softball and enjoy the ensuing no-hands rest. Tricky moves up and back right a bit before traversing left to join the last bolt or two of

Quantum Leap

.
content.protection: 8 bolts to chain anchors (shares first two with the Wasp and the last with Quantum Leap), 9 if you clip the last bolt of Escapade. Highly recommend pre-clipping the first bolt.
content.location: Same start as the Wasp, pretty much right where the approach trail hits the Main Wall (between Escapade/Quantum Leap and Master of Defeet).

climbs.name: The Wasp
climbs.fa: FA: John Hooper 5/1964  FFA: Frank Noble 1976

content.description: Powerful moves low down make up the crux of this route.  The Wasp has a lot of variety from slick slab to layback to finger crack to roof crack.  A lot of stances break up the hard moves making it not too pumpy but the crux moves require power and good technique.  It's also good clean aid practice.
content.protection: 2 bolts and gear 0.3" to 2".  The route is difficult and good protection is spaced out 5-10 feet so be up for the challenge if you want to lead this.  Can be toproped, a longish anchor is advised.  One (or both?) bolt has been added to the start since back in the day.  I think that one was well deserved.
content.location: Just at the top of the left approach trail, between Escapade and Master of Defeet.

content.description: Surprisingly fun arete climb above Knob Job. Stay off the ledges to the right (5.9ish).  Definitely worth checking out.
content.protection: 2 bolt anchor.

content.description: Climb a rounded arete on that classic slippery rock.  The way I found the line, this route wanders like an S.  It is quite good with a definite crux near the top when you are nice and pumped.
content.protection: TR.  It appears that this was once led on one bolt.  It would be relatively safe to lead on that bolt (if it were there) because lower down you would get a solid cam and it eases up above the crux.
content.location:
At the top of the Climbers' left approach trail.  between General Dynamics and Exit stage Left.  Use the rightmost bolted anchor for the TR.

You will need to lead Lilley's delight 5.7 hand crack or something harder to set this.

content.description:
Start as

Exit Stage Left

but right at the roof, take the roof crack out and move into the dihedral above. Pro in the initial crack will create rope drag, even with long slings.
content.protection: No bolts, I used an offset nut at the lip the anchors at the top prohibit toproping this climb due to where they`re placed.
content.location: Walkoff to the climbers right.

content.description: This climb uses a variety of powerful sloping side pulls, a few crimps and pinches.  The technical crux is probably between bolts 2-4, but keeping it together until you reach the great jugs after the 5th bolt isn't easy.
content.protection: 5 bolts to fixed anchor.  Helps with drag to sling out anchor.  Can be top roped by climbing the backside.
content.location: Obvious sport route just right of The Thumb Aid Climb.

climbs.name: Sympathy
climbs.fa: Galen Kirkwood, Bob Van Belle, Mike Paul, 1976

content.description: Intense.  The first piece of gear is small but solid.  Once you build the confidence to lead past it, many aggressive moves up thin hands and slippery feet lead you through a good undercling up a thinning finger crack.
content.protection: Very small to 1", 1 bolt.  Aliens useful.  Rap anchor.
content.location: Starts from the ledge above Empathy.

content.description: The climb starts out down and right from a small cave. Climb past two bolts to a ledge, then transition onto the upper face where the route continues up and right to a rappel station.
content.protection: Seven (7) bolt protection. Two bolt anchor. Rap rings.

content.description:
Climbs a wide chimney towards the far left side of the Main Wall.  Scramble up low-angle blockiness to enter the chimney, then after gaining stance atop first large chockstone, chimney up on heavily featured rock to the top.  Climbs at similar difficulty facing either way inside the chimney.

This is supposedly the first technical climb ever done at Mission Gorge, and in all of San Diego County for that matter!!
content.protection: Wide chimney means this climbs as either an unprotected lead or solo, or TR on bolts on top.
content.location: This climb is at the far left side of the Main Wall, just to the right of "The Blocks" and "Knob Job" and to the left of "Rock On".

content.description:
Start on the "Rock On" crack/dihedral; pull onto the block and the first bolt is a little reach to climber's right from there. Move right and up beyond the bolt and if you have a super wingspan like I do you can clip the second bolt from comfort. Then do some fun moves pulling on juggy blocks and slippery feet to clip the third bolt. Few more fun moves and scurry up a slab to the anchors.

The start and belay are in breezy shade later in the afternoon.
content.protection: One or two green (0.75) C4s for the start, then three (four?) bolts. There are rap rings on the wall behind the anchors (you'll be space rapping into "The Chimney").
content.location: Main Wall, Far Left (Photo 1, route 9 in the Messier guide). To the left above the north climbers trail, shares a start with Rock On.

content.description:
A challenging short dihedral crack leads to very balancy face climbing.  During the crux move you appropriately rock onto your foot.  For some however the crack is the crux.  There is also a mantle thrown in there somewhere and a slab finish makes this route quite varied for its length.

The left line of bolts goes at 10b and the right line is significantly harder.
content.protection: A cam about .5-.75 and a few bolts lead to a bolt anchor that can also be accessed by walking up left of The Blocks and traversing right above the route.
content.location: Just right of the prominent chimney at the left side of the Mission Gorge climbing area.  Start up the steep dihedral crack that leads to a small ledge from which you come close to clipping your first bolt.

climbs.name: Rectum Roof
climbs.fa: FTR: John Vawter & Mark Thorpe 1973  FL: Werner Landry 1975.

content.description: Start by climbing up to a thin ledge then up past two bolts to a horizontal crack under a small roof.  Traverse five feet left, using the horizontal crack till you reach a vertical crack that enters the roof overhead; this is the crux.  Pull the roof and jam your way to the top till you reach a bolted anchor. This route should protect well, but the leader should be comfortable with the grade.  A toprope can be set up on this route to work out the moves.
content.protection: This is a mixed lead that requires small gear up to three inches and also protects with two bolts.  There are also bolted anchors at the top for rappelling and toproping.  Double length slings will do the trick for a TR.
content.location: This climb is located on the Main Wall Center; Upper Tier Routes.  Continue up past the Gallwas Crack to another ledge and gain purchase on top of a large boulder; should be able to see the two bolts at this point.

content.description: Start on the owl, move to a bolted seam that leads to a horizontal crack and finishes with some moves on a small ledge-y face. The first couple of bolts can be clipped with a foot in the crack system of The Owl. Many of the initial and final moves are insecure, but the crux is in the middle of the seam. The Mission Gorge PDF describes this climb as starting on the first few moves of The Owl, but the newly placed bolts would suggest that a variation with a more direct start has since been climbed at a [much?] harder grade??
content.protection: Start on The Owl with cams in the corner that's followed by 7 or 8 high quality bolts to a bolted anchor with quicklinks. Can do a harder start directly under the route that adds a bolt (8 or 9).
content.location: A bolted right-leaning seam (originally aided?) that starts on a small ledge. Just right of The Owl and a few feet climber's left of Mission Impossible.

content.description: Hard to onsite unless you are amazing, the crux is after the second bolt but it takes some finesse and power to get through it then keep your head to the anchors. Equally as good as Escapade but it gets 1/2 the traffic.
content.protection: Bolts, use only the first bolt on escapade if you use the second one you will have some rope drag.
content.location:
The right branch off of

Escapade

.

content.description:
Nice crack through rough rock.  On the wide hands side.  Link this up with Crack of Dust.  In fact, you could probably climb them as one long pitch if you mind the gear right.

After you get up this consider setting a TR on Cave Crack off of the bolted anchor (climber's left) for Never Intended.  Cave Crack is an old-school 5.9 chimney.  It starts just left of the Crack of Dust anchor.  Great Steck-Salathe training!
content.protection: Cams, hand to wide hand size. Bolts and rappel rings.
content.location: Basically a second pitch of Crack of Dust but much less slick.  Climb the crack to the right of the anchor.

content.description: Start up Sympathy (intense), and head up and left at the bolt.  Basically an extension of Sympathy that adds on lots of classic bolt protected face climbing.
content.protection: Very small to .5" and bolts.  Rap anchor.
content.location: On the ledge above Empathy.

climbs.name: The Perception of Buzzy Fuzzy Pelt

content.description: Share the dihedral start of the Chicken Fart.  At the end of dihedral, go right and follow crack up to a short squeeze chimney with solid hand jams.  After chimney continue up a right facing corner/crack with a fun bouldery move to finish.
content.protection: Standard rack to 3" Gear Anchor.
content.location: Shares to the start of Chicken Fart.  Between Chicken Heart and The Trauma.

content.description: Climb an overhanging (not a long overhang) hand crack on the left end of Owl Ledge. Difficulty eases to 5.4 after 15 ft. This used to be a 5.6 climb but a large 1000lb flake fell out of the start in 2001 (Or some say!). Currently rated 5.8!
content.protection: Medium cams or stopppers. Descend off rap anchors at top
content.location: This climb is a fairly obvious crack a ways left of the more obvious Nutcracker crack and Gallwas crack.

content.description: A slick overhanging mantle followed by delicate stemming up a shallow dihedral, finishing with the top 10 feet of hangmans climb.
content.protection: Bolts and a cam placement.
content.location: In the recess immediately right of hangmans climb

content.description: Just left of Escapade, climb a dihedral up to a small roof. Climb over the roof and finish up a slab to a large ledge.
content.protection: Gear anchor
content.location: Just left of Escapade

content.description: Crack starts thin and gets wider.  Very slippery rock the whole way up the right facing dihedral.  At the top a small traverse right is needed to gain the chimney which is shared with The Gallwas Crack.  The word that best describes this route is "athletic".  It will literally take your breath away.
content.protection: Small to possibly large (for the middle third).
content.location: Main wall, starts up on a ledge near the top of the left climbers' loop trail.  Starts on the right side of this ledge, left of The Gallwas Crack.

content.description: Quite sustained and steep sport climbing leads to easy slab climbing.  Bring some finger strength along for this one.
content.protection: Bolts.  Bolt anchor (no rap rings).
content.location:
Directly above Crack of Dust.  Effectively a second pitch for any climb ending on the ledge above Crack of Dust.

Walk off left and then follow the 3rd class descent for the climbs at the far left of the climbing area.

content.description: A very unique experience in the heart of Mision Gorge.  Traverse along the top of the Main Wall.  We did left to right but it probably goes well both ways.  Decent hand jams in a horizontal crack that splits the entire main wall.  Feet tend to be greasy as usual at the Gorge.  Many awkward moves throughout the climb but no real show stoppers.  The holds just open up right when you need them.  Make sure to protect your second!  Only follow this route if you would also feel comfortable leading it.
content.protection: Full rack from Black Alien to #4 Camalot.  Nuts not that useful.  Slings to clip rusty anchors along the way.
content.location: Start at the top of Crack of Dust.  Rightmost anchor on the ledge.  Finish on top of a pillar of The Wasp.

content.description: Crimpy start leads to the first crux between the first and second bolts followed by a tricky 5.9 ramp and the final crux - an impossible roof on slippery rock. Belay from the flat ground above the trail.
content.protection: 6 bolts to quickclips
content.location: The Owl and Razors Edge to the left. Plumbline to the right

content.description:
Thin face climbing that will force you to work on good footwork leads to a cool lieback on the Finn past frictiony rock.  A few more moves will take you to the anchor that appears to have been moved up and left since the FA.

Apparently you can toprope an 11 to the left of this climb on the same anchor (haven't tried it yet).

I'd give it 3 stars but it is short, even for the gorge.
content.protection: 2 bolts / bolt anchor.  Both lead bolts were replaced 6/2007.  Anchors look bomber.  Walk off top.
content.location: Starts above the anchors for Mariah and Hangman's in a wide chimney.  A short climb in an obscure area makes an available alternative when in the area.  A hiker can get even with the middle of the climb making for a good photo op if you have an extra person handy.

content.description: Start up a shallow, slick, dihedral.  Move straight up the dihedral to the third bolt, and then traverse left for about 15 feet onto brownish rock.  From there continue on to the top.  This route shares its 5th bolt with Empathy.  Crux is probably passing the slick terrain between the first and second bolt.
content.protection: Five bolts and a two bolt anchor with rap rings.
content.location: Five bolt line to the left of Empathy and to the right of the Wasp.  Note: The start of the route is also to the right of the aid route Misbegotten, although it crosses over this route past the third bolt.

content.description: Climb up in to a small cave, then pull the roof out of the cave and into a pod.  Pulling the roof is the crux of the route.  From the pod the crack widens from thin hands to offwidth.
content.protection: Standard Rack for protection. Two bolt anchor. Rap rings.

content.description: From the belay scramble up into a cave on easy terrain. Pulling the roof sets the grade on this otherwise unremarkable climb.
content.protection: Standard rack. Two bolt anchor.

content.description: A shallow and discontinuous (filled with dirt), small to medium crack, in the middle of a laundry chute-like feature.
content.protection: Small to medium gear. This route used to have cold shut anchors on the wall at the top of the ledge. You will now have to sling some large rocks or build a gear anchor.
content.location: Route 35 in the Messier guide. Right of Exit Stage Right. Finishes on a large ledge that provides access to Main Wall Upper Tier routes (Gallwa's Crack, Nutcracker, Rectum Roof etc).

content.description: Climb a rib of rock through a roof.  It seems unlikely however the rib provides the holds you will need.
content.protection: TR.  Easiest way to set up is to lead Lilley's delight (5.7 hand crack) and head right to the bolted anchor.
content.location: At the top of the left climbers' approach trail.  Left of General Dynamics (bolted) and right of Lilley's Delight (easy crack).

content.description: Climb left variation start to Knob Job, instead of stepping right at roof to mantle the Knob. Pull the roof directly via excellent side pulls and under clings, to a wicked left side pull flake/horn, to mantle!
content.protection: When top roping use large oak tree as your anchor. Use left bolt of Knob Job Anchor to clip 48" directional to climbers end, to prevent Ugly Dangerous swing over into 4th class ramp.
content.location: Located just left of Knob Job.

content.description: Climb up and right, then traverse left to an unusual bulge, which is the crux of the climb.  An awkward, but fun climb.
content.protection: Top rope. Two bolt anchor.

content.description: Steep climb utilizing a well textured surface with decent sized holds and solid feet. Utilizing the opposing wall for some wide chimney moves is likely considered off route, but can makes this challenging  climb do-able for most experienced climbers. Route merges with Cornered on the arete for the finish
content.protection: Bolted Anchor, no bolts on route
content.location: The left side of the block which holds two other routes to include Absornine Junior, and Cornered. Block lies atop the main wall climbs: Mariah, Hangman, but in my opinion is most easily reached ascending "the Chimney"

content.description: Fun face climb smack dab in the center of the wall. E-guide calls it 5.10. Will test your balance. There is also a 5.9 to the left.
content.protection: Large gear or sling the tree.
content.location: Up and to the left of Knob Job.

content.description: The difficult portion of this climb is right at the start between the 1st and 2nd bolts with some interesting footwork.  The climb follows a ramp up and right, then traverses back to the left to a V slot.
content.protection: Five (5) bolt protection. Two bolt anchor.

content.description: Starts directly beneath Gallwas Crack and follows up discontinuous blocky terrain to a small cruxy section about 15 ft up.  Move right at the cruxy, slick bulge, match feet, and pull up on surprisingly good, slightly hidden hands to a small slab. Move up slab, back left and set up a gear anchor either by slinging boulders, or by placing high at the beginning of Gallwas.
content.protection: Some good small pro. Got a couple of medium nuts and blue/orange Metolius in.
content.location: Directly beneath Gallwas Crack. To the right of Laundry Chute.

climbs.name: General Dynamics
climbs.fa: Galen Kirkwood, Bob Van Belle and Mike Paul in 1980

content.description: A roof which requires quite a bit of power to pull through leads to a ledge, then more delicate moves up a flare.
content.protection: 1 smallish cam and 2 bolts, bolt anchor.
content.location: At the top of the left climbers approach trail.  The roof and 2 bolts make the location fairly obvious.

content.description: Left facing dihedral on the main wall.  Thin fingers start (can be avoided to right) leads to a classic dihedral finger - hand crack.  This crack leads up slippery stone to a chimney.  The chimney adds a different element to top off a long (for The Gorge) section of jamming and stemming.
content.protection: Mostly smallish gear.  Nuts or cams will do.  Stuff in the grey alien range (.4 camalot?) is good.  Biggest piece I remember using was #2 camalot.  Even the chimney doesn't require wide gear.
content.location: Main wall, starts up on a ledge near the top of the left climbers' loop trail.  Starts on the right side of this ledge.

content.description:
Excellent low ball boulder problem traverse, that climbs right to left across the majority of The Main Wall.

Obviouse crux just before scramble to start of The Owl.
content.protection: Ok landing.
content.location:
Start anywhere in the vicinity of The L Word. Traverse left staying low.

Ends at Crack of Dust.

content.description: A couple of bolts lead past tricky climbing to a finishing manlte move.  The climb is slippery and the crux down low.  Be solid at the grade if leading so you don't pitch before you make the first clip.
content.protection: A couple of quickdraws for the lower section.  The first clip is kinda high and hard to reach.  Be careful.  Some gear is likely to be found before the mantle.  Had to bail right due to a TR in the way, so I can't say exactly what the gear will be.
content.location: Starts on the far left side of a large ledge on the Main Wall.  Right of The Crack of Dust, scramble up to this ledge (10').  The climb starts just left of The Owl Crack.  Consider using it as an approach pitch for Never Intended (5.10b).

climbs.name: Exit Stage Right / The L Word

content.description: Short route with obvious right traverse underneath roof. Lackluster route, but provides access to Gallwas and Nutcracker
content.protection: Medium sized pieces. Bolted Anchor.

content.description:
The crux of this route is the deceptively slick traverse, exiting left, from the roof after climbing up a dihedral crack.

Note:

Please make it a point to lead this climb on your next visit to Mission Gorge and comment on the suggested grade. I thought the traverse was a bit too slick for 5.9
content.protection: Standard rack. Two bolt anchor.

content.description: An excellent sport climb with sustained technical moves and slippery stances. This route involves climbing on small features and slippery sloping rock.  Moving up to clip the third bolt involves a very cool stemming move to reach a large two-handed hold allowing a secure clip of the third bolt.
content.protection: Seven (7) bolt protection. Two bolt anchor. Rap rings.

content.description: Thin flaring crack to the right of Mariah / Suzie's Wild Ride.  Crux is pulling over the top with dirt for handholds.  Feet can come out of the crack toward the top to smear.  Bolt anchor at the top, but far back so extend it with your climbing rope.  More climbs start from the top-out ledge.
content.protection: Med-large nuts, #2 & .75 camalot is what I use.  Save a .75 camalot w/ extension runner for the top.
content.location: To the right of Mariah / Suzie's Wild Ride by about 50 feet.

content.description: Interesting and technical face climb between The Wasp and Lilley's Delight. Start up the bolted face 20' to the right of The Wasp, following the bolt line closely as it moves gently left and up...too far to the right and you encounter easier terrain near Lilley's Delight (5.8); too far left and you find yourself on the thinner and slippery-er Master of Dafeet (5.11). Bring your partner up after you and tackle Sympathy or Prime Directive next for the best "multi-pitch" climb at the Gorge!
content.protection: 5 bolts, bolt anchor
content.location: Approach via the Main Wall trail. Route is just above and right of the point where the trail reaches the wall.

content.description:
A less slick variation to Chicken Heart.  Head up the V notch 15 feet right of the Chicken Heart start.  Clip a bolt then traverse left and up (crux) to finish up to the Chicken Heart anchor.

A good variation including stemming, face climbing and crack climbing.
content.protection: Start is easier but runout.  You could work in some small pro.  One bolt (ASCA replaced 8/2008).  Cams .5" to 2" for finishing crack.
content.location: Start 15' right of Chicken Heart, finish at same anchor.  Next area just left of the Lunch Rock area.  Rap anchor.

content.description: A cool arete toprope problem.  Climb up the corner looking on both sides for crimpers, slopers, and footholds.  No showstoppers, just good continuous climbing.
content.protection: Toprope from bolts.  Two oldest of 3 old bolts pulled a new one put back in one of the remaining holes 6/2007.
content.location: Above the anchors for Mariah and Hangman's.  Obvious looking arete that is on its own tower.

content.description: Offwidth/squeeze chimney. The climb starts on the second tier above crack of dust and to the left of never intended. Begin in a cave and work your way into a squeeze chimney that narrows to an offwidth.  (There are often loose rocks and dust in the crack, so be careful not to dislodge anything onto folks below).
content.protection: Wide pro. #3 - # 5 Camelot minimum (wider if you have it).  Can also be top roped off the anchors on never intended with a # 3 as a directional.
content.location: Above crack of dust and to the left of never intended.

content.description: Start slightly right of crack of dust following a thin crack as it curves right.  Near the top you clip a bolt from a ledge and mantle straight over onto a second ledge.  Rap rings are to the right (shared with crack of dust, fingerrip and the owl).
content.protection: Small cams, nuts, and 1 quickdraw for the bolt.
content.location: Right of crack of dust and left of fingerrip.

climbs.name: Buckwheat
climbs.fa: Joel Tracy, Greg Williams, Skip Taylor 1994

content.description:
Climb a bulgy roof up past some good holds to some bad holds.  There are really 2 cruxes, the obvious one is getting up over the bulgy roof and the other comes higher when the handholds thin out.

If you plan to lead this a really tough guy would start up Masters of Defeet for one enduro pitch.  Wimps like me TR this by tunneling to the top, passing Gallwas Crack on the way.  Not sure if a 60 would get you all the way down to the ground but a 70 just might.  Be careful.
content.protection: Bolts.  Hang out up above Masters of Defeet at the bolted anchor to belay.
content.location: Starts up high above Masters of Defeet, right of The Wasp.

content.description: Start up Nutcracker, veering off to the face on the left at the well chalked flake. Figure out how to get established underneath the small roof of the bulge, crank over it into some powerful liebacking to a jug. Breathe and finish up on easier ground.
content.protection: 5 bolts, plus a piece or two for the start of Nutcracker, rusty bolted anchor
content.location: Shared start with Nutcracker (right end of ledge above trail, scramble up on the left side)

content.description: Climbs a wide blocky crack system that narrows down to a thin hands crack (with a ledge for feet) near the top.  Crux is moving from a double crack into the the thin hands crack near the top. Good first trad lead.  Often top roped.
content.protection: Small to Medium gear.  Two Bolt Anchor at top left.
content.location: Located to the right of Nob Job and to the left of the Chimney.

content.description:
Climb the grim crimps up middle of Triangle block, V3 boulder problem, until it becomes possible to grab and mantle apex of triangle. Good rest at half way point here and only opption for pro to protect the headwall BP Crux. Even though protection is bomber you will deck if you blow the crux mantle.

Can also be TR safely.
content.protection:
Cams .3 .5 .75 and stoppers to #9.

Can protect the finger crack entering the blocks crux, then down climb back to keystone will result in a bad swing. Guess it's better than decking. Also watch getting clipped by top of Triangle Block would be really bad to flip upside down from catching this feature.
content.location: Starts on obvious Large triangle block just left of the start of the Blocks. Crux climbs thin side pulls between top of Knob Job and The Blocks.

content.description:
Climb the right arete of this formation (Cornered is the left arete). Moderately slippery and balancy start goes behind a shrub and up to a few tough and tricky moves, putting you into a few slabby mantles to the top.

Be very careful routing the rope on this one, lots of weird angles and edges at the top waiting to catch and chew up the rope.  Easiest to have the belayer to the left of the start.
content.protection: Bolt anchor, walk off.
content.location: Behind the rap rings for Mariah, you can also hike up from other areas to get there.  Near Mickey Finn and Cornered.
